entry.question: If the card I play with a blue battle icon also has other battle icons, do those count in the battle?
entry.answer: Yes. For example, if it has orange battle icons, those will add to the character’s attack total. If it has a green battle icon, it can be swapped with a card in your hand after the battle.

entry.question: Do damage counters already on Captain Elita-1 affect how many I can move onto her?
entry.answer: Yes. For example, if Captain Elita-1 (with 17 health) already has 9 damage counters on her, you can’t move more than 7 more damage counters onto her using her ability.

entry.question: Does moving damage counters from one character to another count as repairing the first character or doing damage to the second character?
entry.answer: No. Any abilities that care about damage being done or repaired won’t affect the move.

entry.question: What happens if I don’t want to play a card I scrap?
entry.answer: The card will stay in the scrap pile.

entry.question: If Captain Elita-1 is my last character and is KO’d, do I get to use her ability before I lose the game?
entry.answer: No. You’ll lose the game just after she is KO’d, before you can use her ability.

entry.question: Can Captain Ironhide take non-attack damage from my cards?
entry.answer: Yes. For example, if you play Photon Bomb, your Captain Ironhide will be damaged.

entry.question: What counts as my opponent’s cards?
entry.answer: Any of your opponent’s characters or battle cards (actions and upgrades) count. Basically, anything that you didn’t bring to the game.

entry.question: If my opponent plays a card that moves damage counters onto Captain Ironhide from another character, will it work?
entry.answer: Yes. Moving damage counters isn’t the same as doing damage.

entry.question: If the Weapon in my hand says “Put on Melee characters only,” can I swap it onto Captain Ironhide?
entry.answer: No, because Captain Ironhide isn’t a Melee character. Any “Put on … only” restrictions will apply. However, because you’re not playing the Weapon from your hand, any restrictions that apply to playing that card won’t matter.

entry.question: When do I use this ability?
entry.answer: You use it before the game begins. After you put the Brainstorm into your hand, you’ll shuffle the rest of your deck. Then you’ll draw the normal 3 cards at the start of the game. This means you’ll start the game with 4 cards in hand (Brainstorm plus the 3 you draw). You’ll still draw a card at the start of your first turn.

entry.question: Can this ability trigger more than once in a the same turn?
entry.answer: No. You play your third action in a turn only once.

entry.question: Can I do anything else with the top card of my deck?
entry.answer: Nope. You can just a glimpse at what’s coming up. You can’t move the card anywhere unless something else tells you to.

entry.question: If I play a Decepticon card or a Secret Action from the top of my deck, does that count as my action for the turn (or my upgrade for a Decepticon upgrade)?
entry.answer: Yes. Major Shockwave’s ability doesn’t give you an extra action or upgrade for the turn. It just lets you pretend the top card of your deck is in your hand when playing it.

entry.question: If my opponent plays a card that tells me to scrap a card from my hand, can I scrap the top card of my deck instead?
entry.answer: No. Major Shockwave’s ability applies only when you’re playing the card.

entry.question: Say the top card of my deck is a Decepticon upgrade. After I play it, the new top card is a Secret Action. Can I play that card too?
entry.answer: Yes. You can keep playing the top card of your deck as long as it meets Major Shockwave’s conditions and you’re allowed to play the card (keeping in mind the normal one action/upgrade per turn rule).

target.name: Major Ultra Magnus - Infantry - City Commander

entry.question: When do I use this ability?
entry.answer: You use it before the game begins. You’ll put Ultra Magnus Armor onto Major Ultra Magnus, then shuffle the rest of your deck and draw 3 cards for your opening hand.

target.name: Private Red Heat - Infantry - Emergency Response

entry.question: What happens if one of the characters has an upgrade of a certain type, such as a Weapon, and the other character doesn’t have an upgrade of that type?
entry.answer: In that case, the upgrade will move to the other character. It doesn’t have to be an “even swap.”

entry.question: What happens if one of the upgrades on one of the two characters has a “Put on … only” restriction that the other character doesn’t meet?
entry.answer: In that case, that upgrade stays where it is. If the other character has a upgrade of the same type, it also stays where it is. Other types of upgrades may still be swapped.

entry.question: Do I count Battle Masters in my KO area?
entry.answer: Battle Masters in your KO area will be in their upgrade mode, either because they were played and subsequently left the battlefield or because you didn’t play the upgrade after the character was KO’d. This means they won’t be characters in the KO area and won’t add to Private Sideswipe’s bonus.

entry.question: When do I use this ability?
entry.answer: You use it before the game begins. You’ll put Force Field onto Private Trailbreaker, then shuffle the rest of your deck and draw 3 cards for your opening hand.

entry.question: Is the upgrade returned before my opponent flips battle cards?
entry.answer: Yes. Notably, if the upgrade gave your opponent’s character tough, the character won’t have tough when it’s time to flip battle cards.

entry.question: Can I use Raider Road Hugger’s tap ability to give itself an attack bonus?
entry.answer: You can, but remember that using a tap ability causes the character to become tapped. But we’ll assume you have a plan.

entry.question: If I have Runamuck on the battlefield when I flip Raider Runabout to alt mode but he’s not damaged, can I still flip him from bot mode to alt mode?
entry.answer: Yes. The effects work separately.

entry.question: So that means I can still repair a damage from Runamuck even if he’s already in alt mode?
entry.answer: Correct.

entry.question: Can I use Raider Storm Cloud’s ability to give itself bold 3 (or bold 6)?
entry.answer: You can, but remember that using a tap ability causes the character to become tapped. Hopefully it’s a good plan.

entry.question: Sergeant Cog is a Weaponizer. That sounds awesome! What’s a Weaponizer?
entry.answer: All the rules that apply to Battle Masters also apply to Weaponizers. Sergeant Cog represents more advanced weaponry. Sergeant Cog’s card is the same size as most characters.

entry.question: Wait, so does that mean I get to play a large upgrade on one of my characters?
entry.answer: Yes. Heavy Force Defensebreaker Cannon is large. It can be played onto any character, large or small.

entry.question: Say Sergeant Hound has an Armor, and I play another Armor to replace that one. Will his ability trigger?
entry.answer: Yes. “When you upgrade this” means when any new upgrade is put onto Sergeant Hound.

entry.question: If one of my other characters has upgrades and is KO’d, will Sergeant Skrapnel’s ability trigger?
entry.answer: Yes. Those upgrades were on a character and were then scrapped, so the ability will trigger.

entry.question: Say Sergeant Skrapnel has an upgrade and takes damage exactly equal to his health. Can I save Skrapnel using his ability?
entry.answer: No. Sergeant Skrapnel is KO’d at the same time his upgrades are scrapped. His ability won’t trigger in time to save him.

entry.question: Can I return just one Secret Action from my scrap pile?
entry.answer: Yes.

entry.question: When do I use this ability?
entry.answer: You use it before the game begins. After you put the Medic! into your hand, you’ll shuffle the rest of your deck. Then you’ll draw the normal 3 cards at the start of the game. This means you’ll start the game with 4 cards in hand (Medic! plus the 3 you draw). You’ll still draw a card at the start of your first turn.

entry.question: If I move damage counters from one of my characters to another character, will Specialist Ratchet’s ability trigger?
entry.answer: No. Moving damage counters is different than repairing.
